availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Henry English Read (Larue County, KY, congressman (CSA))

body.p: Larue County, Kentucky, sheriff, attorney, soldier, and politician. Kentucky native. Married to Lottie C. Read. Father of William D. Read, Mary D. Read, and Thomas Doran Read. Admitted to the bar and practiced law in Hodgenville, Kentucky, Shelbyville, Kentucky, Elizabethtown, Kentucky, and Louisville, Kentucky. Served as a private and ensign in the Mexican-American War. Sheriff in LaRue County in 1850. Attorney in Louisville, Kentucky in 1860. Unsuccessful Southern Rights candidate for the United States Congress in June 1861. Served in the Confederate Army as colonel of cavalry. Member of the Confederate States House of Representatives from Kentucky from 1862 to 1865.

ab.bibl:
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Kentucky, LaRue County, Hamilton District.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Jefferson County, 7th Ward City of Louisville, p. 101.
Confederate Applications for Pardon and Amnesty, NARA RG 94, Microfilm Series M1003, Roll #0026.
“A Brave Man’s memory . . . Courageous Career of Col. H. E. Read,” Courier-Journal (Louisville, Ky.), July 23, 1882.
Acts of the General Assembly of the Commonwealth of Kentucky, Passed, vol. 1 (Frankfort: A. G. Hodges, State Printer, 1854), 188.
Find A Grave, "Henry E. Read (1824-1868)," Memorial #6865338, http://www.findagrave.com/memorial/6865338 (accessed January 12, 2017).
Ezra J. Warner and W. Buck Yearns, Biographical Register of the Confederate Congress (Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1975), 202-203.
Lewis Collins and Richard Collins, History of Kentucky, vol. 1 (Collins & Company, 1882), 353.
